Legal_Issue: Unauthorized use of trademarks in promotional packaging
Evidence_Assessment: Visibility of plaintiff's trademarks on promotional book packaging associated with Konica film
Burden_of_Proof: Plaintiff demonstrated a serious issue to be tried and potential irreparable harm
Credibility_Factor: Likelihood of consumer confusion regarding association between Konica and the plaintiff
Legal_Rule: Sections 9 and 11 of the Trade Marks Act prohibit unauthorized use of registered trademarks in connection with wares or services
Standard_of_Review: Balance of convenience and irreparable harm test for interlocutory injunction
Grounds_for_Claim: Konica's packaging implied association with plaintiff's trademarks without authorization
Outcome_on_Merits: Not decided; preliminary finding of substantial issue to be tried
Review_Standard: Serious issue to be tried, irreparable harm, balance of convenience
Procedural_Fairness_Assessment: Fair hearing conducted prior to interim relief
Key_Evidence_Considered: Packaging design featuring plaintiff's marks on Guinness Book of Olympic Records bundled with Konica film
Legal_Framework: Canadian trademark law under the Trade Marks Act
Applicant_Challenge: Preventing continued alleged infringement during litigation
Legal_Rule_Source: Statutory: Trade Marks Act, Sections 9 and 11
Standard_of_Proof: Lower threshold for interlocutory stage: serious issue to be tried
Defendant_Response: Not detailed, but use was part of promotional strategy
Evidence_Type: Documentary and circumstantial evidence of packaging use
Outcome: Injunction granted restraining Konica from marketing film in contested packaging
Legal_Provision: Sections 9 and 11 of the Trade Marks Act
Legal_Provision_Cited: Sections 9 and 11 of the Trade Marks Act
Grounds_for_Inadmissibility_or_Allegatio: Unauthorized use of protected trademarks in commercial promotion
Applicable_Process: Civil litigation procedure for intellectual property infringement
